title: 103_hr4962
content: The Act titled "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" establishes a management conference for the Coeur d'Alene Basin under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference is established to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. The conference includes members from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. Additionally, steering committees are appointed, and ex officio members are included. The Management Conference, including ex officio members, must publish a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin within a year. The plan will clarify duties, funding methods, and schedules for programs and projects. The Management Conference must publish a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin within a year. The plan should describe funding methods, incorporate environmental management concepts, and include a strategy for water pollution prevention and control. Public review and comment on the draft Plan will be conducted in Idaho. Upon approval of the draft plan, the Administrator shall approve it within 30 days. The approved plan will be considered a management program under section 319(h) and a comprehensive conservation and management plan under section 320. Grant assistance may be provided to various agencies for water pollution control purposes. Grants are available for assisting in the development of the Plan, with a federal share not exceeding 70% of the costs. The non-Federal share can be provided through in-kind services. The Administrator can establish terms and conditions for grant administration. The term 'Coeur d'Alene Basin' refers to a specific watershed in northern Idaho. The Coeur d'Alene Basin in northern Idaho includes the South Fork of the Coeur d'Alene River, the main stem of the Coeur d'Alene River, and Lake Coeur d'Alene. This section does not affect the jurisdiction of any US or State department or agency, or any entity related to the Basin created by treaty. The Environmental Protection Agency is authorized to receive necessary funds for fiscal years 1995-1999. SEC. 3. FEDERAL PROGRAM COORDINATION. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, will enhance data collection in the Coeur d'Alene Basin by developing an integrated geographic information system, converting recording sites to monitoring stations, and establishing additional monitoring sites for basic data collection and groundwater mapping. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will establish a fisheries resources restoration program and conduct a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to conduct a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including surveys of various species and migratory bird populations. This is to improve the health of fishery resources in the area. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to improve the health of fishery resources, conduct investigations on fishery resources, disseminate information to interested parties, and periodically update a survey of fishery resources and habitats in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-1999 to carry out these activities. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will cooperate with natural resource trustees to develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This includes creating a geographical information system inventory of mining sites and contaminated areas, and cleaning up these sites. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes cleanup of mining contaminated sites, restoration of natural resources, stream and river restoration plans, monitoring of restored areas, and development of a land management plan to reduce health and environmental risks. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes developing an integrated geographical information system, wildlife and fishery habitat management plans, monitoring wildlife management areas, and collaborating with various agencies for public recreation. The Coeur d'Alene Basin plan involves collaborating with various agencies to develop an integrated public recreation management plan and a lake and river information program. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory of mining waste source areas, data management, and acquiring mining contaminated lands for restoration. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to restoring and managing mining contaminated lands, designing and maintaining restoration projects and facilities, overseeing construction of repositories for mine waste, implementing a lake and river information program, developing long-term restoration and land management plans, and providing maintenance for restored public lands. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-2002 to support these activities. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM CERCLA LIABILITY. The EPA and DOI are exempt from liability under CERCLA for actions taken under this Act.
